content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												This game looks promising, and could have potential, but ends up wasting what it has with clunky controls and with just how short the game is.First off, the good points. The graphics are very good, especially the water and the way it flows between rooms. The near-future sci-fi setting is above-average and shows quite a bit of promise.Unfortunately, the bad points significantly outweight the good for this game. The controls need quite a bit of work. For simply walking around they're fine, but the jumping controls are extremely spotty. I died far too many times because the character wouldn't jump or would jump the wrong direction. Also, the cover system doesn't work consistenly (won't always go into cover when you need it, randomly can't shoot around corners, sometimes randomly jumps out of cover) which makes some of the firefights later in the game quite frustrating.The sci-fi setting, as interesting as it is, is woefully underutilized. The game supposedly takes place on a floating city, but you never actually see it (the quick glimpse out the window at the beginning notwithstanding). For all I know this could be in a secret underwater base or in tunnels deep below a conventional city.The water powers are a cool concept, but the clunky controls combined with the fact that you don't actually get them until almost the end of the game and that there is only really one power was a big letdown since it was one of the selling points of the game for me.Finally, the biggest weakness of this game is just how short it is. I blew through it in 4 hours without a walkthrough and with dying a significant number of times due to the controls. There is no closure on the story (unless it's in a hidden video after the credits). Sure, you stop the bad guys, but what happens to the city?I feel like the concepts behind this game are solid, the setting and the basic gameplay ideas are spot on, but the poor execution and lack of content really hurts this game.Unfortunately this game is from 2011 and it's been a long time since the last update so I'm not confident that there will be any further improvements. Not recommended.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Hydrophobia is a puzzle/action/platformer akin to games like Tomb Raider, Prince of Persia, Legacy of Kain and countless other titles that we have probably played at one point or another. It's extremely atmospheric and it's got great visualizations (particularly the water effect- no kidding, right?) and sound. Here's the break down:THE GOOD: Stuff I liked.1. The WaterThe water is, as the name implies, the cornerstone of this game. It is the reason for the game's interesting atmosphere and environment based puzzles. The physics, graphics and visualizations (movement of waves, transition from surface to underwater, water on camera, etc) are superb. Best water effects I've seen in a game. Period.2. The Environment Interaction/ MovementI really enjoyed the layout of the levels and their design in general. There was a decent mix of swimming and climbing, giving each zone a level of depth that I don't often notice in other games (save for some of the ones I mentioned previously). Or maybe it's just because I was actually able to interact with it to such a high degree that made it interesting. This includes shooting out glass doors, blasting through bulkheads and raising the ambient water level. Very cool experience.3. NAVI MechanicI really enjoyed the NAVI mechanic. The protagonist comes equipped with a transparent PDA gadget that acts as your GUI in the game, keeping all your notes, grants access to your in game menus, highlights secret messages in the game and enables you to do all your non-combat trickery (hacking, opening doors, etc). 4. PRICE!!! $$$!!I think I bought the game on sale for $0.50? So in the end it was money well spent. ^_^The BAD: Stuff that was 'Meh.'1, Clunky MovementSo, while you can do all this neat stuff like roll, climb, swim and cling to cover... the controls felt somewhat unresponsive. Often I'd lose the ability to shoot around cover and have to back off and re-cling to get it working again. Likewise, occasionally the game would ignore a command to dive, roll, or jump. The fact that it occurred sporadically made it that much more of an aggravation when these missed commands would pop up... particularly in a heated, combat situation!2. *Occasional* Camera Angles from HellAgain, these didn't happen very often but when they did it was really difficult to get out of them. It most often happened while swimming and most usually in tight corridors. Of course, this is typically a problem of any game with a high degree of mobility in a given environment. 3. BacktrackingI don't mind a whole lot of backtracking personally. Given the NAVI's ability to help you perceive new things in the environment and the changing level of water, I'd rank this game about equal with such games as Legacy of Kain and Chrono Trigger. OF COURSE, there's backtracking... the designers want to show you how a place has changed. So I don't think it's a problem, but a lot of other reviews did. 4. 'Easy' Combat...?I played the game on Normal mode and died a total of 2 (maybe 3?) times while in combat. The badguy AI is fairly responsive in my opinion: when you don't shoot at it, they sneak closer to you. When you do, they scramble for cover. They try to flank you, etc, etc. They don't do any of this quickly, but they do it. They also deal enough damage that you can't go barreling in guns blazing very often either. But, if you're like me and you rock the sneaky/cautious/clever game style, you'll probably breeze through the game since there's ample opportunity for you to use environmental hazards to your advantage. This is NOT Call of Duty, Counterstrike, or anything resembling a "real" shooter. It just happens you can shoot things. 5. Voice ActingI've seen a lot of bad reviews because of voice acting... but honestly, I've heard a LOT worse (none come to mind this instant, but we've all heard worse). Plus, there's not a whole lot of it. I actually think the worst voice acting comes mainly from the protagonist (which is unfortunate) because I thought the acting of the antagonist and your plucky tech support ally were decent enough (if not reading from a very unimaginative script). THE UGLY: Stuff that's unforgivable (imho). In order,1. Repetitive game play and goals. The whole game is about finding keys to locked doors, almost without exception. This sucks. I'm just glad the environment was fun to navigate to make me forget that this was all I was doing. Blah. 2. Very few upgrades/collectables/etc. You pick up about 3 'new' abilities that you use sporadically throughout the game. There was also about 6 different types of ammo you could collect... but you really never needed it until the end of the game. This is one extremely crucial difference between this game and the likes Legacy of Kain and Prince of Persia (also games like Metroid, Castlevania and Megaman)… you never really feel like your power level advances.There is one HUGE exception to this complaint however, which brings me to...3. INCREDIBLY SHORT GAME!The final and coolest upgrade you get in the whole game is discovered and unlocked LITERALLY minutes before the game ends at the one and only boss fight. Not only is it a cruel move to throw a new game mechanic at you without giving you sufficient time to practice using it, but you also don’t get to enjoy it for more than a few minutes! Unforgivable! >_<Overall, if you can snag this game for less than the price of a bottle soda at the gas station AND have a few hours to kill, you may as well pry what fleeting joy you can from it’s very beautiful, if somewhat flawed and arthritic fingers.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												You can now (07/03/2014) save 90% on this gem! I believe you should all proceed as you're not gonna regret it!Dark Energy's Hydrophobia is an action-adventure game that takes place in an underwater city. This is what the game's antagonists (terrorists) are trying to get rid of by placing bombs at several places to have it completely destroyed by water.Now, here comes the interesting part: Kate, the girl you control, can manipulate water. While you have the usual cover-shoot-cover-style gameplay you also have the option to move water - this looks and feels amazing thanks to the technology incorporated in the game that makes sure handling water is as fluid and dynamic as possible.The game can be difficult at times and being an indie game it does not have top-notch voice-acting. Also, being an indie game it is rather short - doing a complete walkthrough can be managed in 3 or 4 hours. Nevertheless, I recommend this game especially due to the regular discount it receives - another proof why we should look for some indie titles in between those AAA titles.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Having bought this for $2 or somesuch ages ago, I'm stunned at how good this game is. The flaws -- mostly m+kb control-related for me -- need no pointing out, and were apparently pretty glaring on first release, but it was expanded and improved, and I'll list the high points that really stand out for me:1) Story and plot development. The slow way the player is introduced to the world of HP is just fantastic. No big cinematic intro or information dump on who your character is or where you are, and it's only through small details like pictures or found documents that some background is unveiled. When the bombs start going off, you're just as clueless as your character, rushing around to put out the next fire or repair a sub-system. I'm really impressed with how well the plot unrolled, how involved I became with the character, and still think about the unanswered questions.2) Graphics and water effects. Great stuff. Much of the gameplay revolves around the excellent and ever-present water effects, and I became just as anxious as the character about drowning.3) The 'Mavi' device; what a nice in-game tool: A tablet-like device that your character holds up, and that displays an enhanced wireframe view of your surroundings, with objectives and points-of-interest highlighted. An intuitive and well-designed HUD element, that's only there when your character deploys it; every time I used it I congratulated the devs on thinking it up.Well, those are enough. For $2 & a short 7 hour campaign, there's more than enough reasons to give Hydrophobia Prophecy some attention. Runs fine under Win8.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												I'd like to think there was a really grat idea... that was just never fully realized, or they just didn't quite know how they wanted to effectively pull it off. See, it's one thing to advertise a game with having an ability, but it's another to save this until the last chunk of the game. There are some well implemented ideas, unfortunately, none of which go well with what the intended vision might have been. Combat mechanics are awkward, some of the controls a tad unresponsive, and you're never completely clear on exactly how you're supposed to accomplish certain tasks. Oh, and you'll likely die a lot from trial and error trying to either figure out how to solve a puzzle, or drowning. Usually the latter.I like the cover mechanics, although it's probably best to stick with the Sonic Rounds, since not only are they the highest accuracy, but they also don't have ammo, and you charge them. And you can use them underwater. Of course, your enemies can use shotguns underwater... which is kind of cheap if you ask me.I wouldn't say this is a terrible game, as there are elements that do work... sort of, but I probably wouldn't recommend this, unless they decided they really, really wanted to try this.[SPOILERS]Now... if they had allowed you to use your "waterbending" powers a lot sooner, like say... I dunno, before the end of the first act, I think it could have easily been a much better game. Alas, that's not the case, and unfortunately, there's only a few short segments where you can try out your new powers, and it's incredibly short lived. Plus the ending is kind of like they were trying to close it as quickly as possible. It's awkward.

Posted: December 9, 2014
												Quite a few people seem to be giving this game bad reviews, and honestly i can't see why. Personally I had a great time playing this game and it was alot more than I had expected for the price. The game mechanics and controls are great, in fact they're alot better than most games i've played. Shooting while hiding behind cover was well done, and I enjoyed the underwater gunfights. Another thing i liked about this game was the hacking system which is simple but effective. Needless to say, the water looked awesome and the physics to go along with it worked well. The game looked and played amazingly, and the voice acting was passable. The only issue I had was a bit of frame rate drop near the end of the game, which is understandable considering all the water physics. Overall I throughly enjoyed this title, and consider it one of the better game purchases i've made. I find myself wishing there were a sequel, as not many affordable games turn out as great as this one. Would definately recommend!

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												My recommendation is conditional -- this game is not worth full price. However it routinely goes on sale for 90% off (so I paid $0.50), and at that price I think it's worth it. I just finished my first playthrough which took me about three hours; I could run through it again once or twice to pick up medals/achievements I missed, and I've also unlocked a "Challenge Room" that I haven't played yet.The mechanics are fun, and the water physics is great. In most games, water just makes you walk slower as you're moving through it -- in this games, water actually exerts force on you and the environment, so a wave of water flooding a corridor will shove you back and carry debris with it. Thanks, Havok physics!The controls could feel a little clunky, and the story was completely underdeveloped. I thought I was fighting a mid-game mini-boss battle and then the game was over. If you somehow become emotionally invested in your character and her helpful friend, you'll get no resolution whatsoever.Overall -- $0.50 is worth it for an afternoon of playtime with some fun water physics, but this wasn't a Game of the Year by a long shot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This is a tech demo showing of water physics, and that's about it. The models are pretty, the water physics look nice, but it's terrible beyond that. I can imagine the situation, "Good work, fellow 3d artists, we've made a nice looking game, and the water physics have raised the industry bar! Wait, where's the guy with the game mechanics? We don't have game mechanics! Ah well, slap on some third-person cover shooting, some shoddy climbing mechanics, and a hacked together story led by a whiney protagonist."Combat is a bit of a mess. You get a sonic gun that non-lethally takes down enemies, but they immediately drown in water, so there's no point in a no-kill run. But if you can get past that, the thing can push explosive barrels in enemy faces that are hopelessly floating in water, that's fun.  Climbing is boring and irritating. One moment I'm a one woman army fighting against misguided terrorists, the next I'm suffering with a terrible camera slowly jumping up some pipes and trying to judge where I'll land from jumping to the next wall. To be honest, the climbing killed the game for me. The campaign is short enough for you to complete in a couple of hours, but I doubt you'll complete it due to a jump at the end in which if you mess up, you have to start about 5 minutes back to where you started, and you'll be messing that jump up a lot. I don't even know what's past that jump, I raged and left after about seven attempts.Though I'll give the game credit where it's due, but it's not enough to redeem it. The combat is a mess, but playing with the physics to kill your enemies is fun, a la Half Life environment kills. Story wise, it started off alight by having memorabilia explain the protagonist's background, but then collapsed when she started talking. Jesus, can that woman whine. Then you got the "We're killing everyone and everything, including us," terrorists. My eyes rolled out of my head when I saw the doomsday machine. Recommendation: Buy it to play with the physics and look at the pretty water, that's it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
												Hydrophobia: Prophecy is an odd mixture of a third person shooter and a platform game about Kate, an engineer working on the greatest ship of the ocean, the Queen of the World, in a futuristic setting. The game takes place during an unexpected terrorists attack on the ship, with Kate trying to survive the whole ordeal as the ship is filled with water and other environmental hazards. Notice that Hydrophobia was originally released as an Xbox arcade game and was tweaked/remade two times before being reborn as the version you can buy here on Steam, Prophecy.The main objective of the game is to navigate the Queen of the World while trying to survive the rampant hazards within (water floods, fires and electrical sparks): Kate is able to jump, swim and move on ledges, as well as to carry around items to clear her path. An important tool for the exploration is your hacking tool, which can be used to unlock doors and see through the eyes of the security cameras. Truth be told, the whole level advancement does feel repetitive and, beside the varied platforming sessions, you are mainly tasked to find the next code you can use to open the door blocking your way.Hydrophobia also features firefights against the invading terrorist forces. In this regard the games plays out as a typical third person shooter, with your only available gun being a LP 4 sonic pistol, which can be equipped with several kinds of ammos. Truth be told, however, the stock sonic bullets will be the only things you'll ever need to clear Hydrophobia and, unlike the others, are infinite. Something I'd like to point out though: it's really hard to actually get where your enemies are coming from, which can quickly lead to frustration as you die for the third time because you couldn't get to your attackers in time.The title has also some collectables in the form of documents or logs scattered around the levels (with some being less obvious than others to find) and medals, which pretty much counts as in-game achievements. There is also a challenge mode, which isn't very notable.The main problem I have with Hydrophobia: Prophecy is that, despite the great presentation and the well crafted environments, they hardly make up for a very short game (I clocked it around two or three hours) which doesn't make good use of the many interesting elements it puts on the table. I'd advise to try it out only if you get a really good feeling from it

And too bad the developers/studio is closed, so the sequel is unlikely.How much I like this game score: 6/10 - I like it, but the series is dead, and I hate it. But still like it.How much I want to recommend this game score: 5.5/10 - If you are into fps with beautiful water physics, give it a try. If story matters to you, skip this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												My friend bought me this title for 49 cents. I did not expect much, but at least the game met those expectations.It is the start of a new century. The story follows a young women named Jane Wilson, a surprisingly fit lady who works for a nano-robotics company. It is revealed at the start of the game that she is hydrophobic, which is ironic, since this game involves lots and lots of swimming (more on that later). She needs to stop a terrorist organisation focused on destroying her workplace and everything it stands for. The gameplay brings nothing new to the table. It is a third-person shooter, with a single weapon but with multiple types ammunition. The most useful ammotype in the game (and arguebly the most powerful) is the sonic blasts. Unfortunatly this renders the other ammotypes nigh useless, creating a great imbalance in the gameplay. As I said previously, the game involves alot of swimming. While underwater, I often found myself fighting the unintuitive controls. There is a mechanic which restricts the amount of time the player can spend underwater, before returning to the surface for air. One can also get involved in bouts of underwater combat, which is less exciting than it sounds.Speaking of combat, overall, it is definitely on the feeble side. The best way to clear out enemies, that I have found, (keeping in mind that I played it on hard) is to headshot them with sonic blasts from behind cover. This is not really a game where run and gun tactics are that effective. Taking cover is always your safest bet. In general the combat is not that difficult   and can be quite repetitive. The game uses an interesting way of pointing you towards objectives. The player uses a transparent tablet-like device and holds it infront of the screen. This presents a sort of augmented reality that indicates the location of objectives. This device is also used for hacking. Hacking is more rudimentary than it sounds and is just used to open doors and hack security camaras. Sometime the player needs to hack control panels. This involves a minigame, where the mouse is used to control the amplitude and the wavelength of a wave. The player needs to match these variables to those of a another wave. This is also very easy, but surprisingly fun (I am a bit of a geek :-) ).And then there are the powers. The pictures of this game leads one to believe that they are an integral part of gameplay. Unfortunately they are not. The powers are only introduced near the end of the game. Making the players experience with them far to short to justify their existence. Speaking of too-short, this game can be completed in six hours if you are playing on hard difficulty. And much quicker on the easier ones. This is much too short for my taste and makes me feel that the developers shouldn't have released this game in its current state.Now for the million dollar question (or whatever you pay for the game) Is it worth it?For 5$, no.For 1$, yes.I give it 5\10

content:
Posted: January 3, 2013
												Seeing this game on sale often at $1.24, I decided to take a chance, thinking how bad can it really be? So, going in with my expectations low I was surprised to find an OK game here. While HP has several flaws, none of them are game braking or frustrating, other than the occasional micro stutter which can be distracting. Being a huge Tomb Raider fan I see it's influence here and can only guess that the dev team wanted to make a TR game in water. While the TR-ish foundation is there, the puzzle solving, jumping and climbing, and combat, all of these are under utilized and so sporadic that most of the time you're just left to play in the water, which is the main focus of the game anyway. Although I have to admit, the effect is kind of cool...YAY!! *splash splash*Overall, the lite game play elements/mechanics are done just well enough without feeling like a chore and I did find the game enjoyable enough even with the barely there story and the meh voice acting. Surprisingly, it actually kept me entertained enough to finish the game in one sitting. If you're a TR fan or enjoy that type of gameplay, I would say give it a try at $1.24, you could do worse with your money.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												It's an indie game and you can see it was created on a tight budget as the ending feels a bit rushed for my taste. Nevertheless is it a surprisingly good game with some interesting approaches to gameplay mechanics e.g. hacking terminals and of course the phantastic water. As you'll do a lot of platforming it is worth mentioning that the movement controls are solid. As Hydrophobia was first released on XBLA it supports Xbox controller although playing with keyboard and mouse is no problem at all. What you get on steam is a reworked version of the game with better graphics and one different character model with new voice acting - I like the original scottish accent better. Please compare Xbox vs Pc version on youtube. The game code feels not very optimized for Pc . I play titles like Metro Last Light or Crysis 3 with ease in max settings in 1920x1200 while my HD 7950 doesn't get noisy whereas Hydrophobia seems quite taxing in max settings. So if you own an older pc or a low spec laptop you may be forced to turn down the graphics settings.Checkpoints are well placed and fair meaning you don't have to replay lengthy sequences if you're dying. The only bug I noticed was a clipping error in chapter 2. You will get  as average gamer 6 hours of gameplay out of it.If you're asking yourself if it is worth buying - definitely. If it's on sale you can get it for a few cents so why would you miss out on it? There are  choices far worse you could make. My conservative rating is a solid 7 out of 10.

												This game is a mess. Sure enough the water physics are great, but that isn't enough to carry it all. The controls are horrific, something I oddly enough only noticed during the final act of the game. For a game with a lot of water-based gameplay, the swimming controls are really cluncky: only willing to resurface when you hit the space key, only willing to dive when you hit shift. I only spent about 50 cents for this and for that money it wasn't really a bad purchase. It did manage to entertain me for about an hour and a half. But I cannot recommend this to anyone, it is simply too bad a game.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Hydrophobia: Prophecy  --- AN PASSIBLE DIVERSION (BUT ONLY BECAUSE IT'S SHORT)Third-person (mostly) platformer/adventure with some shooting. I was well aware of this games reputation for not being all that great. Most of the conversation revolved around "pretty water", "short", and "boring gameplay". While I mostly agree, I have played worse (and uglier) games and for $ 0.49, it was an adequate game experience. LOOKS: The game is fairly pretty graphically but the main character and most character models are trite and boring.Overall, I was surprised how nice the graphics were despite my (purposely) lowered expectations. Of course, the games claim to fame, the water, is fantastic. It rolls, splashes, pours through doors, and ripples quite realistically. It even reacts to explosions and your sonic gun. SOUND:I don't have too much for sound. It mostly adequate. Rushing water sounds nice, explosions are...explody, etc. However, the voice acting is awkward and annoying. This mainly applies to the protagonist and "Scooter" as the others were at least passible. The problem is compounded by the unnatural dialogue that just didn't flow naturally. GAMEPLAY:It's an OK game. Not really much  of a shooter as it's very light on enemies. It too linear to be a real adventure puzzle game. You never really have to think too much. The computer screen tools used in game is a nice addition to spice up the game some. I just wished they did more with it. The weapons are adequate but the intial weapon is all I ever needed. CONTROLS:Solid. Aside from occasionally missing my backward jumps, I never really had any control issues. I tried out both the gamepad and keyboard controls, and they each worked well as a control scheme. LENGTH:Really short. Felt more like 1/3 a full game. However considering the less-than-riveting gameplay, the length is just about right. STORY:Besides the water physics, the backstory was the most interesting part of the game. I felt that it was a good backdrop that was unfortunately underutilized. Furthermore, several story elements were hinted but not actually exploited fully. Pacing was awkward and there was no real character development to make you care about anyone dying (including your own character). All of that, along with the weird almost drowning as a child thing that never was explained, really amplify the "we intended to do so much more" vibe of the game. BUGS:I did notice a few odd graphical glitches. After dying once, the level seamed confused as to what state it should be in (i.e. pre- or post- explosion) so it compromised and gave me the pre-explosion level with the post-explosion decorations. Also, I think I failed to quit properly once and it erased my whole game. However, it was merely took 10-20 mins to get it back as I already knew the way and you can (blessedly) skip cutscenes.SUMMARY:Not great by any means. Play if you want a diversion. It'll keep you interest long enough to get you to almost the end, then you have to just muscle through the last 15-30 mins.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a typical adventure game, with lots of innovative uses of water. At its core, the gameplay is similar to other games in the genre, but the game uses its setting and environment to its advantage. The result is an interesting game and experience as players navigate through water filled environments.The game is set on a floating city, which is attacked by terrorists who take control of the entire place. Kate, a systems engineer, gets involved in the mess and has to escape to safety, fighting the terrorists along the way. The story for this game is quite linear and not exactly an amazing story. There are a few good lines by the characters though to break up the flow of the story a bit. In addition to the linear story are optional objects and documents in the world, which provide additional backstory and perspectives on the characters and events. With a decent story to keep players interested in the game, it functions well enough to fit the main gameplay attractions in and provide a bit of depth to those interested in reading up about the world.For the most part, gameplay consists of getting to certain objectives on the map using a single route. Getting to these places is done by some platforming, climbing, or swimming. There are tools that are unlocked later on, which are a scanner and a firearm. In addition to getting to places on the map, there are also some puzzles that need to be completed to go on to the next area. The gameplay is honestly a bit on the simple side with these mechanics being pretty basic, but it’s serviceable to play through. The biggest part of the game is the water as the title suggests. Due to the water’s realistic nature in this game, it has a major impact in how players have to work with and use water to their advantage. Opening a flooded door sends water rushing in, which fills up the room with water to swim in. This water feature can play a huge role in firefights, as the battles shift to fighting underwater in flooded rooms. Littered around the map are various objects to collect, which can be collected for achievements. These objects make the game focused more on exploration for players that try to soak up their surroundings and find things around the world. It makes for a nicer experience to step back and see what hidden things were placed around and to try and find them. The simple adventure gameplay might be off-putting for those wanting something more complex, but the usage of water is done in a great way that makes the game play and feel unique.The setting is a floating city in the near future. On the whole, the game uses a realistic style, though at times the graphics do look a bit dated. The water looks amazing though, with some of the best water visuals around. The developers really nailed getting the water to both look and flow in a realistic manner. Since the water is such a major component of the game, it’s good that the water effects are very appealing when playing and interacting with it.Alongside the realism focused graphics is the soundtrack. The music for this game is comprised of both traditional and electronic instruments. It’s nothing particularly distinct, though it does help that the music is dynamic based on ingame events and helps to give cues on what’s going on. Overall it’s the water graphics that shine the most, with the other content looking good enough to make a fine game.Hydrophobia has some standard adventure gameplay and a straightforward plot, but the usage of water does make things interesting. The short length and typical story and gameplay might not be wanted by some. For those wanting a short game that is simple to pick up and play and has some awesome use of water, Hydrophobia is a good game in that regard.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												This game is a must buy if you enjoy all aspects of water!I did hit a few game breaking bugs near the middle (which is to be expected of any well made game), but when I quit and came back to the game later on, and my saves had been deleted forcing me to start again, I was like yeeeeaaahh!! that solves that issue! I also heard talk of there being a few problems with the elemental physics, like the random placement of electricity or the amount of fire in the water, but you have to ask yourself, why wouldn't a big ship-city be filled full of oil and napalm, and have exploding barrels in every room?I'd also like to thank the makers for giving me the opportunity to hate the characters of this game with such passion! from their horrible grinding voices and the way they move, right through to their terrible (or just never mentioned) back stories. The people who made this game must have worked so hard! I read a few bad reviews, but come on guys, I know there's been a lot of complaints about the special powers that you only get to fight the last boss with, which I know is one of the reasons you bought this game, but you did get 5 minutes to play with the powers in that moving blocks to make a bridge room on the way there, so don't be greedy!  and while we are talking about it, I thought the pushing 4 buttons at once system (using the controller), to use your water magic gave us excellent control, and the lack of a tutorial for how you use them just made the game delightfully challenging, like when I fell down that elevator shaft to my death 20 times in a row.When I first started playing and found that it was just another game based around a silly gimmick with boring linear fps and cliche wall climbing gameplay and rubbish graphics that was made to demonstrate their water physics engine to prospective buyers, I was disappointed, but by the end when I'd pulled out all my hair and was crying into my hands, I really began to appreciate this game.

The water physics and effects are impressive, the graphics are pretty good, and the voice acting is decent.  I would stop short of calling it "Great". Gunplay can be fun, but I wish they emphasized stealth aspects more than straight up battles.  The story is passable, but the ending leaves a lot to be desired.  You can play the whole thing in 3-4 hours, but this was designed as a downloadable game for consoles too, so there was no expectation this would be a full fledged AAA.  Besides, you can pick it up for only a few bucks.  All in all, not a bad deal and a decent way to spend a few hours.

It's not very long, and it doesn't have a proper ending or wonderful plot, and it does have some fiddly bits.However, if you go into it expecting a tech demo, I think you'll be much more impressed. content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												I was actually really liking this game, and ready to give it a rather positive review, until I encountered by far one of the♥♥♥♥♥♥poorest final boss battles in GAMING HISTORY.  First of all, it's the ONLY boss battle in the entire game.  Secondly, it's at least two to three times harder than any other part OF the game, and requires the mastery of a completely new skill you only gain ten minutes beforehand.  Thirdly, it appears to have no checkpoints throughout its excruciating length.  Fourthly, it's inconsistent as a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and what worked the last time won't necessarily work the next (half the time I successfully threw explosives at the boss robot, the other half I merely succeeded in blowing MYSELF up).  All I can say is: THANK GOD FOR YOUTUBE.  Oh, and your reward for beating the boss?  One of the briefest and most abrupt (and I don't mean "John Carpenter's The Thing" kinda enigmatic; I really do just mean ABRUPT) end cut scenes ever.  Rarely before have I witnessed a final fifteen minutes of a game which seemed so...tacked on, and thoroughly unsatisfying.     And maaaaan...I was really looking forward to defending this game against all the naysayers.  I'm still gonna thumb it up and give it a reasonable score, but ONLY because it was so enjoyable (borderline ENTHRALLING, even!) earlier on.  If you don't mind a 4 to 6 hour game with an ending you probably couldn't be ♥♥♥♥ed completing, feel free to pick it up on sale (i.e. for LESS than five dollars).  For those who require a bit more narrative closure, you may want to give this wishy-washy mess a bit of a miss.Verdict: 7/10.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												"The ultimate edition of the jaw-dropping action-adventure game set onboard a floating city."That's the description for this game given on the Steam store page. I dunno about any of that. "Jaw-dropping"? This game wasn't even *bad* enough to make my jaw drop, let alone be amazing enough to induce jaw dropping as they imply. "Floating city"? This game could have been set inside an underwater facility for all that it matters that it's a floating city. In fact, I'm incensed that it isn't because 'floating city' implies a more interesting setting than a simple underwater facility and this game is NOT INTERESTING in any aspect.The story is insipid, worse, there's no conclusion whatsoever. The final boss battle ends and the game does so as well, abruptly and without denouement of any kind.You see the little splash image of the protagonist using some kind of water powers? That's almost a lie. You don't get those abilities until the last 10% of this game, and you only really get to use it for one move in the final boss battle.The crappiness of this game really comes out when you are trying to do anything more complicated than standing still and shooting. When the action gets hectic and I need to dodge, aim, shoot, and use the water powers in rapid succession, it's like the game gets confused and faints. Inexplicably, she'll get stuck pointing her gun in one direction and not only am I unable to shoot but I can't change direction anymore either. Moving the mouse moves the camera freely around her but does not change where she is actually facing or aiming (not that it matters, since I can't shoot). This game has absolutely nothing of substance to offer as an experience. The only interesting thing about it is technical: the water uses realistic fluid dynamics. The best I can say about it is that it is not "offensively bad" like, say, Surgeon Simulator. Unfortunately, unlike Surgeon Simulator, this game is simply not fun.Incidentally, this will be the very first game I've ever given a Not Recommended rating. Make of that what you will.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Hydrophobia: Prophecy is 3rd person survival-horror style action-adventure game. While the PC keyboard/mouse controls are fine, the game also has platforming elements, as well - so, I wound up using the X360 Controller for this one. While the graphics are not spectacular, they are good & do get the job done just fine here. The water looks stunning. The voice-acting is good, though the story could use a little more kick & depth to it. The water in this game is its own creature, as it will effect the environment & its surrounding - especially since feels like it has weight to it. Using the environment for combat is another thing that makes this game stand out, since you really don't have very many weapons or skills at your disposal...until later on in the game. When it's all said & done, Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a pretty good start to what looks to be a series that could have a lot of potential, if they keep on building on the nice foundation that this game actually sets. Grade = B-

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2012
												Hydrophobia isn't a great game, but I've played worse. Playing style is similar to Tomb Raider, climbing around ledges to progress to the next area, with some basic 3rd person shooting vs enemies with poor AI. Weapon variety is poor but opportunities for environmental kills keep it fairly interesting. No huge Tomb Raider style puzzles though. The big draw of the game is the water physics. As the ship falls apart and water rushes in knocking you off your feet, there is a sense of panic, trying to get to safety before you drown. The story and voice acting are decent, but some plot threads are left unfinished. Feels like the first part of a larger game. Its unfortunate that the 3rd act goes all action, ending with a fairly frustrating boss fight. You get an interesting new ability very late which ties into the story, but don't really get chance to play around with it before the game ends. I finished in under 5 hours, but still value for money when on sale for £2.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a 3rd person action game by Dark Energy Digital. The game has some amazing water physics, but unfortunately that is all it really has going for it. The game play is mediocre and the platforming that the games throws at you is not very good. The graphics are decent, but not enough to justify the frame rate drops that I would get for no apparent reason on my 7870 O.C. It seems like the game was not optimized good enough and was not able to keep a steady frame rate on a decent rig. The story was fairly interesting, but not enough to carry the game for me. The voice acting wasn’t the worst that I have heard but it was far from being any good. I played the game for about an hour and decided to retire it. Time to move on to another game in my backlog, hopefully one that is fairly good this time.Pros:-	Amazing water physics. Some of the best that I have seen in gaming.-	Fairly interesting story.-	Funny characters.Cons-	Poorly optimized. I had constant frame rate drops on my overclocked 7870-	Poor voice acting for most of the characters.-	The Platforming is not very good.-	The combat is fairly Generic for what I have played of the game*Please note that I did not finish the game. I would recommend checking better sources from people who have finished*

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Let me begin by saying: NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO! FUUUUUUUUCK! GOD BLOODY DAMN! NOOOOOOOOOOOOOO! NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO! That would just about sum up my vocal experience while playing this game. I'm gonna begin by saying the ONLY good thing about this game, IT'S SHORT! I finished the main campaign in 3.2 hours, THANK GOD for that... One more hour and I would've been on the six o'clock news with a KNIFE LODGED INTO MY BRAIN!!!Why? WHY NOT! The first hours of this game are not that bad, it's divided into 3 acts, with the first act being a 15 minute mission, and the other two acts being two 1 hour-long missions... Coupled with a boss fight at the end. I honestly don't even know where to start naming all the problems this game has.. At first it looks like a flawed little budged game, but that's not bad, right? WROOOOOOOOOONG! After the first 30 minutes, the problems start to begin. I think I'm going to count them all, let's see how many we can get.1. CAMERA ISSUES, OF-♥♥♥♥ING-COURSE! Camera is so bad, it's HORRIBLE! Unresponsive, derpy, going all over THE GOD DAMN PLACE! 2. CONTROL ISSUES. Irregular controls. What works NOW won't work 1 minute later. Jumps and "climbing" parts are RANDOM AS F*CK. 3. ENEMIES APPEAR OUT OF NOWHERE! I SWEAR TO GOD, I've seen enemies pop up RIGHT IN FRONT OF ME, and not teleporting from another location or anything, just SPAWNING RANDOM ENEMIES IN MY FUUUUUUUUCKING FAAAAAACE! 4. Accuracy on your weapons is BLOODY♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!! Most of the times you're gonna fight with a pistol that shoots one bullet per second and you're gonna miss most of the times. But then you're gonna get some auto ammunition for your weapon and miss ALL THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ TIME! 5. And what would bad accuracy be without PERFECT ENEMY ACCURACY? Yes, you heard it.. AIMBOTTING ENEMIES! Not only they appear in YOUR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ FACE, but they also shoot like 999999 bullets per second in your face with perfect accuracy! 6. And what would perfect accuracy enemies be without also being A GOD ♥♥♥♥ING DAMN BULLET SPONGE!!! SOOOOOOOOOOOOOO MANY SHOTS THEY TAKE... FUUUUUUCKING RAMBO OVER HERE, each and every one of them!!! - Take into consideration that all of these flaws are on the EASIEST DIFFICULTY, so don't go around telling me "lower the difficulty idiot"...7. Like I said many, MANY enemies everywhere appearing out of nowhere but also coupled with the usual enemy "benefits". There are quite a few underwater combat situations and guess what, enemies that spawn underwater have FAHKING GILLS! Just sitting there underwater forever, shooting you, without you seeing where they shoot from..8. Incredibly bad final boss fight.. Again you get more of the same infinite enemies spawning besides you while you try to juggle with the 999999999999999999999999999999 simultaneous STEPS that you have to take to just put a TINY DENT in the boss, and you have to do that for like 5-6 times before you defeat him, so.. arm yourself with patience.. and a STRAIT JACKET!Honestly, it's such a bad game, it's not even funny. There are more flaws than this, rest assured, but I just finished the game and I'm still incredibly angry. I honestly am amazed I'm still alive and didn't jump from the roof of my building yet. This game made me RAGE more than ANY OTHER GAME MADE ME RAGE, EVER! And I played a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of games in my 21 years of life...♥♥♥♥♥♥ controls, aimbotting enemies, bad accuracy on weapons, crappy camera, crap-ton of backtracking for objectives... I don't even know why I bother writing reviews for ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games, all of them have the same damn issues, I should write a general review and copy-paste it for every crap game I play. Or put it in a text file and just link that text file in every review... The game has a pretty cool concept, and the reallistic water technology is pretty awesome, it had SO much potential to be a cool game with water powers, but no, you only get ONE water power and that's in the LAST 20 MINUTES OF THE GAME, would've been so cooler if you would've got it earlier in the game, but noooooo, we can't do anything to entertain our players, can we? The execution and gameplay of this are HORRIBLE and shallow! I hate my life right now, this game destroyed me, I'm going to cry myself to sleep.

The voice-acting is good, though the story could use a little more kick & depth to it. The water in this game is its own creature, as it will effect the environment & its surrounding - especially since feels like it has weight to it. Using the environment for combat is another thing that makes this game stand out, since you really don't have very many weapons or skills at your disposal...until later on in the game. When it's all said & done, Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a pretty good start to what looks to be a series that could have a lot of potential, if they keep on building on the nice foundation that this game actually sets. Grade = B-

content:
Posted: October 2, 2011
												This is a decent game with a few problems. It's basically a first-person platformer/shooter with water - lots and lots of water. It's also very short (a few hours), so keep that in mind as well. It has a lot going for it and is definitely a cool game and concept, but the mechanics and gameplay didn't quite meet my expectations. The controls, in particular, I felt were needlessly complicated. The game also didn't run all that well on my PC, despite other more recent games running just fine. Also frustrating was the final boss fight, which was way more difficult than it should have been due to the aforementioned control problems. I also experienced game-halting bugs at more than one point in my playthrough, which could only be resolved by restarting from a checkpoint (which thankfully, are placed liberally). In summary, the overall setting and concept is cool, but it is hampered by spotty controls and a few too many bugs and glitches for my taste. Worth checking out for cheap price.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												Starts off really promising with an interesting setting, rather intriguing plot and the promise of unique combat.Ends up being a cookie-cutter shooter with little extra mechanics. While the water looks rather well and the utilization is alright (the swimming mechanics I really liked, compared to many other games that make you swim and dive through areas) with the mechanics and the hydrophobia of the protagonist, hence the game's title, being displayed comprehensibly, the advertised water control mechanics only become available shortly before the game ends. Which means there is really little to be had, as the expected unique selling points are implemented poorly or just too late in the game.The developers are bankrupt, apparently, and it seems as if they ran out of money halfway through the game. I really feel like this game was either supposed to be a trilogy or just a lot bigger. But about 2 or 3 hours in the story leaps ahead, you have a huge room where you must fight many baddies and then suddenly a boss fight, a short and unsatisfying cutscene and then ... nothing. That's it. Nothing is really concluded, nothing really happened. It seems like a prelude to the actual game, which will probably never come.Might be worth a bargain price for the water experience, but otherwise expectations will probably fall short, as the game severely lacks substance.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Ok, there were a lot of fun things about this game. I really enjoyed the first two acts. Especially the climbing bits, and I even got to enjoy the hacking, even though it was timed.Of course, there were quite a few reasons I'd say 'skip this game.' The plot goes from a pace of a car to a rocket jet by the third act. Once Kate gets hydrokenisis (not a spoiler since it's in the screenshots), you barely get any time to really get how it works before you're expected to use it for the boss battle. There are a whole lot of great things about this plot that aren't given a chance to be explained. Malthusians as the terrorists, with calvinist beliefs mixed in there (calling all non-malthusians 'reprobates' meaning doomed to die), an implied overpopulation, the idea Kate is living in a ship due to that... all great ideas, but never really explored to its true potential.I guess I wished for a first level like Half Life's, where the player wanders around Black Mesa and gets an idea of the place before everything gets crazy. The plot summary suggests there will be character arcs, and there aren't. The only thing that changes is that Kate stops yelling whenever she has to go balance on poles. Kate's goal changes inexcplicably part-way through (I suppose her boss being killed might have something to do with it, though he was a jerk to her anyway) from ignoring curing herself and finding her friend to chasing down the bad guy.And it just kinda... ends. This is one of those games where the controls sometimes flat out ignore what you tell it to. Which is especially frustrating considering how unforgiving it is. (There is no saving, just checkpoints.) On that note, this was another game where the hints couldn't be turned off, and they were always brought attention to by an annoying sound. I'm normally not bothered by voice actors, but Kate's voice actor was incredibly distracting. The fact is, this game does a lot of things right, which makes the things it does wrong even more frustrating. What a great world to just ignore.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												I tried to give this another shot. Bad idea. Don't buy it.I once said it was not a bad game. Wrong, it is a bad game. Repetitive gameplay, useless extra powers, terrible checkpoints, terrible camera, and terrible physics. For those who really care, is also has terrible graphics, the only redeaming graphical element is the water, and it otherwise looks unimpressive.Voice acting is also mediocure and does not help the rest of the game. The villan is utterly unimaginative and cartoonish. The collectables are pointless, so they might as well should not even be there.I put it on easy just to get through it, even then the boss battle was brutal. As an example of the terrible checkpoint system, if you fail on this boss, once, they send back to the beginning. Even the fact that they force you to use the terrible extra mechanics in this battle make it all the more frustrating, not challenging. This is where I had to stop, I could not continue.The level design is also really bad, clustered, and full of dead ends. If it was not for the objective markers leading me along the linear path, I would have not known where to go. Linearity is OK, but not with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ level design. This game has ♥♥♥♥♥♥ level design. That is about all I can say on this game. I don't know the nature and resources of the dev team, but even with minimal resources a great game can be produced. This seems to me to be a project that was too big and too ambitious, and as a result just came out... bad. 10/10 for effort, 3/10 for execution.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Don't let it's occasional bargain bin sale price lure you in. For a game that takes a mere 3 hours to complete, the experience quickly becomes repetitive and shallow. Essentially a D-rate Tomb Raider clone, the gimmick here is water and how water influences the game's environments, puzzles, combat, and physics. Unfortunately, the water is overhyped and not enough to make a sub-par gaming experience worthy of your time. While the developers deserve credit for listening to player feedback and releasing two updated versions of the game after launch, the game is currently still plagued with bad design and technical issues like poor collision detection, missing textures, dumb AI, and game-breaking bugs (for some). Gameplay and level design are outright bland. The single enemy type in the game (save for the "final boss") can be easily dispatched with by using your default weapon. There are electricity and fire hazards that can be used to inflict environmental damage upon your foes, but the same tactics are used in every skirmish. The touted ability to control water doesn't even occur until right before the final boss, and at that point it really only seems to be there for that battle. What initially seem like clever and unique puzzles end up being recycled many, many times over the course of the game. With regards to level design, for a ship that is purported to be as large as a city, there are not many places the player gets to see that seem to have had much movement or life in them. The few room variations seen are mostly non-specific server-type rooms and innumerable hallways for the sake of filler. WIthout an in-game guide telling you where to go, it would be very easy to lose yourself amidst the incredibly similar rooms.Controls can be broken into three areas: water, surface, and climbing. Within the water, controls are jittery; hindered by a camera that is cumbersome and erratic, particularly near the water's surface. For a game with such a keen focus on water, having sloppy water controls is unforgivable. On the surface is where much of the combat is found, it is uninspired. Surface controls are heavy and tank-like, and it can be difficult to get out of the way of enemy fire once it starts. When climbing, objects that can be mounted or climbed on are almost always bright red, eliminating much of any thought while moving vertically in the environment.With regards to the writing, the main character and her unseen ally are unlikable. What I imagine the developers were going for was a protagonist/radio ally kinship like Lara/Zip/Alister had in Tomb Raider: Legend. However, between the writing and voice acting, hearing what any character has to say quickly becomes irritating. The game's overall plot manages to be confusing in its brief 3 hours. While it is clear that the ship you are on has been invaded by terrorists and you are trying to make it through said ship, anything beyond that is lost due to poor storytelling. While this game could have brought some interesting concepts to the action-adventure genre, the ideas that were to set it apart were poorly or badly executed, making this forgettable game one to pass on.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Hydrophobia: Prophecy is a 3rd person action game by Dark Energy Digital. The game has some amazing water physics, but unfortunately that is all it really has going for it. The game play is mediocre and the platforming that the games throws at you is not very good. The graphics are decent, but not enough to justify the frame rate drops that I would get for no apparent reason on my 7870 O.C. It seems like the game was not optimized good enough and was not able to keep a steady frame rate on a decent rig. The story was fairly interesting, but not enough to carry the game for me. The voice acting wasn’t the worst that I have heard but it was far from being any good. I played the game for about an hour and decided to retire it. Time to move on to another game in my backlog, hopefully one that is fairly good this time.Pros:-	Amazing water physics. Some of the best that I have seen in gaming.-	Fairly interesting story.-	Funny characters.Cons-	Poorly optimized. I had constant frame rate drops on my overclocked 7870-	Poor voice acting for most of the characters.-	The Platforming is not very good.-	The combat is fairly Generic for what I have played of the game*Please note that I did not finish the game. I would recommend checking better sources from people who have finished*

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												This game has very cool water physics effects. For instance, when you open a door, water from one room will flow into the other and be cut off once the door is shut. Then a wave will bounce back-and-forth across the room until it settles. But other than that this game is bad. It's a standard third-person cover shooter with awful aiming. Every now in then it adds in a hacking mini-game like from the Rocksteady Batman games, or a "platforming" element like Uncharted 2 & 3.The game is riddled with sound bugs, where character dialogue overlaps each other, or characters voices don't come from the correct world locations.The only unique thing about it comes in the last 10 minutes of the game when you get the ability to manipulate water. It's used for 1 puzzle and the final boss fight. That's it.If you love fighting juggalo-looking enemies using terrible shooting mechanics, bland stories, buggy audio, and bad voice acting, then you should play this game.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
Presentation:This game first presents itself to you with a semi-sci fi type world, I like it, anything with a futuristic sci fi world, even more so if it is original is great in my book.You're presented with a female protagonist in this game though, I don't like most games with exclusive female playable characters so that is a bit of a problem. She has a tomboy look going on from a design aspect but that doesn't help in her case because our protagonist is annoying and generic in this game due to poor writing. Her voice actor is terrible as well. Even worse than the voice acting for females in Guild Wars 2.So yeah, the world the game is set in looks nice and is well presented, the female protagnist though is generic and just not interesting.Concept:Very unique concept this game has, I like it. Water is the main elemental focus here, not many games do with the developers had in mind with this game.However, they obviously did something very wrong since the company who made this game went bankrupt and the game engine they designed for it.The gameplay is interesting at first, but ultimately it is just plain, bland, boring. The characters suck, Kate is a junk protagonist, her partner scoot or whatever his name is has halfway decent voice acting but he is boring as well. His animations are terrible as well.Gameplay:Interesting at first, gets boring though. The main aspect of the game, "Water" is not used as much as it should have been, since the developers made a engine based around real physics water the water powers you gain don't show up until late in the game, very silly move on there part to feature the main reason to play the game later on. It should have been available at the start or near the start of the game, would have been more interesting.Graphics:The game looks pretty on my fairly powerful rig, I was very impressed with the HydroEngine that the developers of this game made, they may have gone out of business but they deserve praise for there work on the engine at the very least, I like it.Sound:Not great, below par to be fair. Just doesn't seem good, voice acting is very terrible, music is generic, sound effects does have its moments of being good but most of it is junk, the enemy gun sound effects are a joke, something outta' a cheesy laser tag game.Story:The story is crap. Very basic but not in a good way, the female antagonist sucks, not interesting at all with her overplayed acting and predictable reasoning. Our heroine had potential to be pretty cool, but the voice acting, writing and animations are all pretty bad.Entertainment:The game doesn't have very much entertainment for the $9.99 asking price, I paid only $3.99 for a retail discount and even that seems a lot to ask for, ya know for something that is basically a tech demo for a great innovative game engine. The main reason to play the game would be for the neat water physics, no game has water animations quite like this game, much potential could be had if a major developer like Capcom or Namco got a hold of this engine, but that isn't the case.Replay Value:There is no value in replaying this tech demo, except of you want to experience really nice water physics.Conclusion:The HydroEngine has great potential, the developers should be proud they made a unique game engine with a strong focus on water, If the engine is up for sale, I hope the buyer is a well known or ambitious developer team because the potential to make a crazy hack n slash action game with rpg elements with a water wielding male protagonist seems like a great idea to me. I would love to work on such a project myself if I had enough money and talent to make such a thing happen, I think it would be a very unique concept for a market filled with so many generic first person shooting games.THE GOOD*Ambitious tech demo showing of a unique game engine.*Great and Innovative game engine, the HydroEngine is a unique idea with a poor tech demo showing it off.*Pretty graphics from a former indie developer, on max settings the game looks good. The water is the star though.*Fun physics in general.THE BAD*Main female protagonist is not likable, very boring, even if the character were male he would still be boring.*Bad voice acting from almost every character in the game.*Generic storyline.*Bad writing.*Combat is boring.*Platforming is boring.*Missions are boring.*Support characters are boring.*AI is extremely stupid.Score:4.4/10 ~ I do not recommend this game at the price point of $9.99, it is barely a game. If you can get it for under $5 I would still be very stand offish against it, but to experience the water in this tech demo might be worth it.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												I've had Hydrophobia: Prophecy in my library for a while now. I installed it this morning, beat the game in under two hours and had enough time to get ready for work... Quite frankly i'm disappointed, i was excited for a game with extremely realistic water physics, which is really the only point the game delivered on. The game provided no backstory to the main protagonist Kate. The opening cinematic showed her in some kind of cave flooding with water, and every single time you dive under water  you hear a young girl crying and calling Kate's name.  I was hoping to progress through the game and learn more about her, and the man who pretty much guided you through the entire game, but alas, i got unending quips from him and an almost unlikeable main character. The gunplay (if you can call it that) is mundane, you get one gun which can take 6 different types of ammo, but there are 3 you'll only ever really use. The enemies are equally as forgettable. All we know about them is that they are terrorists trying to get a hold of nano technology to wipe out the human population leaving very few "faithful" survivors. We are still left wondering at the end of the game how they got on the floating city ship, which is hard to believe i'm actually on considering all we see is the inside of it for the duration of the game. The water physics like i said before are all this game has going for it, they are incredible, so i commend the devs for that. However,  when getting your powers near the end of the game (which you use for about 10 minutes if that),  the water physics become clunky and buggy. I disagree with some of the other reviews though, they are not hard to aim as  there is a reticle on the ground for where the pillar of water will come up,  and the final boss was easy, to my disappointment i beat her in about 3-5 minutes if that.The swimming controls could be better, especially during 2 specific sections of the game where you have to  place floating barrels under a submerged cargo container to lift it so you can progress through the level.  I feel like if i tap shift it sends me to the bottom of the water filled room i'm in. I really wanted to like this game, i really tried too, but between the jackass in my ear spouting one liners every 3 minutes for the first hour or so, and the fact the game gives you no backstory at all, with clunky controls, i couldn't. I don't know if i'm even going to start it back up to complete the challenge room. I can't really recommend this game, it leaves a lot of unanswered questions, too many for me at least, and with no real reason why.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												My feelings on this game are incredibly mixed. I bought it during a bargain sale when it was 0.49 euros because earlier i saw a trailer and liked it but didn't have the money. Graphics are great, no doubts there. The gameplay length is reasonably long for such a low-priced game. The water physics resemble From Dust's physics, and your character reacts to it as you would expect, you almost feel the water pushing against your body. However, the storyline is so incredibly dull that i didn't even play until the end. The combat is so simple that if you die once you truly must be new to the game. The game gives repetitive tasks and makes you walk past every place you go twice. Although it's camera hacking system has beaten Watch_dogs, you don't hack much aside from scouting the enemies and using terminals. It's only use is to find out where to shoot. It has so many enviromental ways to kill your enemies that you won't even need to shoot directly at anyone. You get a sound gun and don't even loot the enemy's guns after you kill them. All and all this game is a 7/10 at first glance, slipping to a 4/10 for repetitive and dull gameplay.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Mixed feelings about Hydrophobia. For the price that it often goes on sale, it really can't be beat. 0.50 for some great looking graphics and atmosphere, it certainly does the trick for that much. Why people are calling it a tech demo, I don't particularly understand. It IS a full game - there is a beginning, a middle, and an end. However, I can understand that being instantly thrown into the action with little explanation could grate on peoples nerves. I don't want to say it's Kafka-esque, because that would be giving the game far too much credit, however, the brevity of the story and the nature of it - you're more or less transformed into a bug in this huge maze and you're afraid of getting squished, I  can see some sort of draw to that sort of thing. The game does have non-stop, run faster, finishfinishfinish mentality that's lacking in many games. That doesn't always come across as a good thing. As it's been said before, the water manipulation is a pretty cool feature, but of course it could've been done better. It is smooth in terms of being visually appealing. My biggest issue? The controls. Maybe I'm just not used to third-person games, but pretty much this is the big mood killer. It really, really will frustrate you enough to break something that can be played in a single sitting into multiple play sessions, not because you don't enjoy the game visually, but because you're sick of having to press the exact thing in the exact 0.2 second timeframe they give you to do it. At times it works, at other times, it doesn't work at all. I give it big ups for having a female protagonist that isn't overly-sexualized. This is something people complain about all the time, and it's really not an issue here. The character is pretty, but not flawless and not the commonly associated "Bimbo" flavor you have come to expect from most action games of this type. No overly enlarged breasts, no bouncing wiggling parts for fan service, and the clothes are modest. I really, really do have to give the game points for this - it's something that's not seen often enough and is expected in nearly any game with a strong femal protagonist. The storyline is obtuse, I can't help but feel like there was probably more of an introductory chapter that got chopped out of the game, and that there was much more planned for it that never came to fruition because the development company went belly-up. It's like an early-release title that they just slapped on an "Oh well, finished" tag. They could've issued patches to make the controls less clumsy, they could've opened it up to be played around with and have mods created, they could've done multiple things - bankrupt or not, but they just didn't. And it's short. At most, on the hardest setting, you might get 8 hours of gameplay out of this, and that's only because you're going to die a LOT. Get used to dying, but then feeling really stupid when you figure out where you were supposed to go; it's  almost always completely obvious. This game had so much potential, it still DOES have so much potential, it's not ugly, the main character is pretty cool, the atmosphere is in high levels. Sure, I would recommend it for 0.50 - I would recommend it for 1.99 - but not for the full asking price. A very long, great start to something that just failed. On a final note - the voice acting is bearable. Except for at one point when Alex (The female protagonist) randomly switches to a full-on English accent from a rather non-descript American accent for no apparent reason whatsoever. This only happens for a few sentences, but it still had me shaking my head. If you get it on sale - pick it up, it IS an enjoyable play, but not without its flaws, and within the price range that it almost always runs (Cheap - Very cheap) I can't say I'm disappointed with it. If only they had been able to finish the game - again, it is a full game, I don't know where the tech demo comparison comes from - but opening it up to the community to make their own mods and patches, to create with it, could have possibly saved the company by making it a cult classic. Instead, it's an obscure budget game with atmosphere in bounds and some weird idiosyncrasies that would have taken almost no effort whatsoever to fix. So what happened? 6/10 - Like it, but won't play it again. Well worth it when it's on sale for 2.00 or under or if you get it in a bundle, otherwise, just play something you know you already like.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2014
												What can I say about this game. This game tries it's hardest to make the game mechanics work like some big AAA game like Assassin's Creed, looking at the parkour mechanics, I think it actually tried mimicking Assassin's Creed. Now by mimicking, I mean flat out mimicing, like Shadow of Mordor level mimicking, I wouldn't be surprised if they took some of the coding out of an Assassin's Creed game and tried using it. Sadly, it doesn't work in their benefit, the jumping is terrible, I always end up falling and dying, the climbing is terrible, you can't even move the camera around while doing it, it just snaps back to it's original position. The enemies, oh my god the enemies, I'm going to make a list pointing out all the flaws of the enemy AI:1.) AIMBOOOOOOTS!!!!! Every single enemy has aimbots, no matter how far away you are from them, they will NEVER miss, and this gets even worse when you hear:2.) Enemy detection mechanics. The enemy will be able to detect you from literally a mile away, even if they're looking the opposite direction, they will spot you. This one time the enemy was on the other side of the room, I was in "stealth mode", and they were looking the opposite direction, they still turned around when I came out into an opening and shot me.3.) Knockdown. Whenever the enemy is shot with a near fatal strike, they fall over, now normally this would be fine if they put some icon over them to tell you that they aren't actually dead, but instead you'll walk away from them thinking that they died, only to be killed when they get right back up.4.) OP. Later on in the game you fight stronger enemies who have all these stupid traits on them, so not only do they have the sense of Peter Parker, they have the strength of The Incredible Hulk too.Back to the review, the game itself is very boring and tedious, you usually have no clue what you're doing, the gameplay is repetitive (Get to destination "A" and shoot bad guys along the way, maybe pick up a barrel), and also there's some more in depth things that break down the game as well. During the game, who am I kidding, I'm not even going to put a spoiler text in here, no one is going to care about this, during the game you unlock more weapons such as Gel Ammo, SMG ammo, Full Auto Ammo, and more ammo I didn't ever care to use because they're useless, the ammo you start out with is infinite and is more powerful than all the others if you use it correctly, so it's like you go throughout the whole game never feeling rewarded. The "Stealth" mechanic that they "implemented" into the game is literally useless, there is no such thing as 'Stealth' in this game (as I previously stated during my rant about how terrible the enemies are).Alright, let's list the Pros and Cons.Pros:-Amazing water graphics, maybe the best I've ever seen, also to pair with it has semi good water mechanics, to the point where it deserves it's-Good graphics for an Indie game-Decent voice acting-Boob physicsCons:-Boring gameplay-Glitches-TERRIBLE ENEMY AI-Gross animations-Repetitive objectives-The story isn't even thereI really wouldn't waste my money with this, even if it's on a killer sale.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												Hydrophobia Prophecy isn't very good. But before I get into why, it's not completely awful. Considering it's a 2010 game, the graphics aren't bad, though not amazing. But it's the water physics that is this game's shining crown and glory. The water flows, pours and ripples naturally, not too clear and not too murky. When you open doors or break glass with varying water levels, the water flows from one area to another in waves and levels out. Dark Energy Digital have produced a very good water physics simulator in their HydroEngine. It's just a pity they didn't put as much effort into the game itself.Why did I think this game was bad? Hydrophobia Prophecy aims to be a cover-based, stealth shooter, similar vein to Deus Ex but without the RPG elements. But the stealth elements are absolutely horrible as cover is the only real element that provides stealth. Because the stealth is so bad, the game becomes a generic, watered-down, cover-based shooter. You have 1 weapon with 5 different ammo (i.e. stun, single shot, auto-fire, remote detonation grenade and remote detonation shock grenade). Majority of encounters involved me shooting a guy enough times in the face before he killed me, waiting for my health to regenerate before moving onto the next guy.Hydrophobia Prophecy is only worth having a go if you're interested in water physics in games. Otherwise the game is not very well done due to many flaws and bugs, only being about 3 hours long, poor design and poor mechanics. Dark Energy Digital went under after low sales of this game, which is unfortunately what happens when you produce a sub-par game. More unfortunately is their response to some negative reviews which can be read about in this article. Looking at the title image below, don't get fooled into thinking this is an action game where you use your magical water power to defeat the bad guys. The below image represents about 8.5% of the game, 6% of that being an awful, awkward, out of the blue boss fight.For full review, visit:http://icarusreviews.net/2014/10/03/hydrophobia-prophecy/
